ygData.subject: Re: Looking for a few good men (and women)
ygData.msgSnippet: Fleetwood is lying.  The customer does pay for all of that just like the players would pay if it took that much to do the job. If it took 3 people to make a
ygData.messageBody:
Fleetwood is lying. The customer does pay for all of that just like the
players would pay if it took that much to do the job. If it took 3 people to
make a banded cloak, and those 3 people had to share the money 3 ways, the
average price of a banded cloak would go up from about 20pp to 35-40pp at
least. The guy that drives the forklift doesn't get paid by the government,
he gets paid by Fleetwood who makes their money from the RVs and motor homes
its customers buy. And after the cost of the motor home pays off everyone
involved in making, there's still a huge chunk of money left over called
profit, that Fleetwood uses to invest in other things (what us smiths use to
get some nice plate.) I don't care what they say, corporations like GM and
Fleetwood sell their products at way over 2x production cost...

>From: Talthoron@...
>Reply-To: EQ_SMITHS@onelist.com
>To: EQ_SMITHS@onelist.com
>Subject: Re: [EQ_SMITHS] Looking for a few good men (and women)
>Date: Mon, 12 Jul 1999 17:39:36 EDT
>
>From: Talthoron@...
>
>Fleetwood, the top maker of moter homes and RV's, Pella, the number one
>maker
>of window, GM (which has been mentioned) all will tell you the same thing,
>Screw ups, inspections, the people working in the office, the people who
>drive the fork lefts carting material all day....all the work they do and
>much work that others do is NOT what the costumer buys. The customer buys
>what it takes to make the product and that is all. They are not paying for
>the time it takes to train John Doe, not for the time it takes for someone
>to
>fix or check his work. They do not pay for the people to run the accounts,
>they do not pay for the guy to drive around on a forklift. Would you?
>
>When you buy something, do you want to pay for all that extra that had
>nothing to do with building your car? You can say it did have something to
>do with your car, but the fact of the matter it isn't. Efficency is the
>key.
> If the people doing the paid for work are good enough, then THEY pay the
>cost of all that excess. I don't charge people for me learning to smith, I
>don't charge for failure rates. I charge for my work and the matrials
>needed
>to make the given item. I have about the same prices. I guess I just
>value
>my work more then you do yours.
>
>Talthoron
>
